story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Follow latest updates as evacuated British nationals undergo 14-day&nbspquarantineAll British nationals have been urged to leave China due to the coronavirus outbreak, as the epidemic claimed more than 420 lives and infected more than 20,000 people globally.Meanwhile, British officials are continuing attempts to trace 239 people who flew to the UK from Wuhan, the city at the centre of the outbreak, before travel restrictions came into force.Some 94 UK nationals have been evacuated from the city to Britain and are now undergoing 14 days in quarantine at Arrowe Park Hospital on the Wirral.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesFollow the latest updatesDeath toll rises to over 420Total number of infections rises to more than 20,000British nationals urged to leave ChinaMore cases expected in UK, health secretary saysBritish officials trying to trace 239 from city at epicentre of outbreakBelgium reports first case of coronavirusThe Department of Health has said 414 people have tested negative for coronavirus as of Tuesday.&nbspTwo patients with the virus are still being treated in Newcastle.Uzbekistan has evacuated 250 people from China and will place them in quarantine when they arrive in Taskhent, the country's state airline has said.&nbspUzbekistan Airways said in a statement the passengers were being accompanied by doctors and specialists with protective equipment.A 23-year-old British man who believes he has contracted the coronavirus is trapped alone in the locked-down city of Wuhan and fears he may be left behind by the British authorities.Jamie Morris, from New Tredegar in south Wales, fears&nbsphe may have contracted the virus at the end of November, before the mass outbreak prompted global media attention.They diagnosed me as having potential pneumonia but couldn't confirm it, he told the PA news agency.&nbspI had all the symptoms, literally everything that has been said by the government, however it was before the virus was made public knowledge.There is a high possibility of it being so, but thanks to my high immune system, I managed to beat it back.&nbspHe said he had not been able to get on the flights back to the UK because he had recently given his passport to the Chinese government to lengthen his residency permit.&nbspThe news of a British evacuation came very quickly, leaving many people who lived a fair distance from the airport unable to make the flight, Mr Morris said.Royal Caribbean&nbsphas cancelled eight cruises which were due to depart from&nbspChina in the next month.The company – which already cancelled three trips scheduled for February after consulation with health authorities – said it expects the cancellations and some modifications to its itineraries to reduce earnings by 25 cents per share.Royal Caribbean also said it would deny boarding to people who had visited mainland China or Hong Kong over the past 15 days. It will also screen Chinese and Hong Kong passport holders and people showing flu-like symptoms.&nbspThe decision comes as thousands of&nbsppassengers and crew on a US-operated cruise ship are tested for the coronavirus&nbspin Japan after one passenger was found to have contracted the virus.Japanese health officials are&nbspconducting extensive medical checks on all 3,700 passengers and crew of a cruise ship that returned to the country after one passenger tested positive for the new coronavirus.&nbspA number of people on board are ill, officials have said,&nbspthough no one else has yet tested positive for the fast-spreading virus.&nbspThe US-operated Diamond Princess returned to a port in Yokohama, near Tokyo, late on Monday, ending a 14-day tour during which it stopped at Hong Kong and several other Asian ports before returning to Japan.&nbspJapanese government and tour company officials say they were notified by Hong Kong that an 80-year-old male passenger who got off the boat on the island tested positive for the virus.A coronavirus vaccine is a long way off, a health expert has warned.&nbspSuch a vaccine will not be ready in time for the current outbreak said David Heymann, professor of Infectious Disease Epidemiology, London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine.&nbspA vaccine is a long way off, Prof Heymann told a briefing at Chatham House in London. There will not be a vaccine probably to deal with this outbreak, but there is work being done on coronavirus vaccines in general. I'm confident that there will one day be a coronavirus vaccine.&nbspHe continued: Sars caused major outbreaks when it was exported from China, major hospital outbreaks - that hasn't yet happened in this outbreak, this disease so that's one point to compare.That's not to say it won't happen in the future but it hasn't happened yet. The world is much more prepared to deal with these things now than it was then.More than 100 Malaysians have been quarantined after being evacuated from Wuhan.An AirAsia plane carrying 107 Malaysians and their non-Malaysian&nbspspouses and children landed at the Kuala Lumpur airport early on Tuesday.They immediately underwent medical screenings, and the National Disaster Management Agency said two people who did not pass the screenings were immediately taken to the hospital.Medical workers in Hong Kong have gone on strike for a second day to demand the border with mainland China is shut completely in an attempt to limit the spread of the coronavirus.&nbspAll but two of Hong Kong's land and sea crossings with the mainland were closed at midnight after more than 2,000 hospital workers went on strike on Monday.&nbspBut on Tuesday, health authorities reported two additional patients without any known travel to the virus epicenter, bringing the number of locally-transmitted cases up to four.&nbspAccording to the Hospital Authority Employees' Alliance, the strike organizer, more than 7,000 members joined the strike to demand closure of the border across which tens of thousands of people continue to travel daily.Britain's National Union of Students has said it is concerned about reports of Chinese students experiencing discrimination and hate amid the coronavirus outbreak.&nbspErica Ramos, from the NUS, said: The NUS believes that all forms of hate and prejudice are unacceptable and shall continue to support students’ unions on any issues they may face around hate crime and xenophobia.&nbspWe have a continued responsibility to ensure our spaces are inclusive and accessible to all students, any student facing these issues should get in touch with their student’s union.”&nbspMalaysia has reported its first citizen to be infected with the coronavirus, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in the country to 10.&nbspHealth authorities said the 41-year-old Malaysian had travelled to Singapore for a meeting last month with colleagues from China, including one from Wuhan, the epicentre of the epidemic.&nbspHe only showed symptoms on 29 January, nearly a week after returning to Malaysia.More coronavirus cases are expected in the UK, the health secretary has said.&nbspSpeaking before a meeting with Germany's health minister, Jens Spahn, Matt Hancock said the UK was working with other countries to research a vaccine.&nbspWe haven't seen the peak of the coronavirus by a long stretch and we expect more cases in the UK, he said.We have a full plan in place to treat all those who have symptoms and test positively for coronavirus and we are working with international partners both to slow the spread and also to do the research that we need to do to find a vaccine.&nbspMr Spahn said no matter the future relationship between the UK and EU it was important they continue to co-operate.He added: The virus obviously knows no borders and is a threat to all our citizens. What's important for the international community is actually to join forces when it comes to research, when it comes to detecting the virus and combating it.&nbspWhatever might happen for the future between the EU and UK I find it important that there is good co-operation.Singapore has announced its first local coronavirus transmission, with six more cases being reported.&nbspFour of those were local transmissions, linked to a health products shop that primarily serves Chinese tourists, the country's health ministry said.&nbspThe other two were Singapore residents evacuated from Wuhan on Thursday.&nbspThough four of these cases constitute a local transmission cluster, there is as yet no evidence of widespread sustained community transmission in Singapore, the ministry said in a statement.&nbspIt takes the country's total number of infections to 24.On Monday,&nbspChina accused the US&nbspof spreading fear by pulling its citizens out and severely restricting travel.Washington has unceasingly manufactured and spread panic, said Hua Chunying, spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry, noting&nbsp the WHO had advised against trade and travel curbs.It is precisely developed countries like the United States with strong epidemic prevention capabilities and facilities that have taken the lead in imposing excessive restrictions contrary to WHO recommendations, she said.&nbspThe US&nbspCentres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) defended the measures taken by the US, including suspending the entry of foreign nationals who had visited China within the past 14 days.New coronavirus cases have been reported in the US, including a patient in California infected through close contact with someone in the same household who had been infected in China.It was the second instance of person-to-person spread in the US after a case reported last week in Illinois.We expect to see more cases of person-to-person spread, said Dr Nancy Messonnier, director of the National Center for Immunisation and Respiratory Diseases at the US&nbspCentres for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).Six new cases of coronavirus have been reported in Thailand, including four Thai nationals, the country's health ministry has announced.&nbspThe four Thai people included a couple who had visited Japan and two drivers who had picked up Chinese passengers in Thailand, the ministry said.Vietnam has assigned the military to quarantine 950 Vietnamese returning from China at two military camps outside Hanoi for at least 14 days,&nbspthe official Voice of Vietnam Radio reported.&nbspDuring the time of quarantine, anyone of them showing symptoms of fever will be transferred to a hospital for treatment, the report cited Nguyen Viet Thang, Hanoi's military chief medic as saying.The total number of coronavirus infections in China rose by 3,235 to 20,438, and there were at least 151 cases in 23 other countries and regions.&nbspThe World Health Organisation (WHO) has declared the flu-like virus a global emergency.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: sir keir starmer voters humble beginnings
story: But the frontrunner to seize the Labour crown has certainly moved a very long way from his humble origins.Apart from being a knight of the realm, the posh Trot has pocketed almost £, for providing legal advice since he became an MP five years ago — working out at an eyewatering £ an hour.This is on top of his generous salary for his day job of nearly £, a year, a combined income far beyond the dreams of ordinary voters.His Momentum buddies might also question the legal company he keeps.Several law firms who defend businessmen in bribery, corruption or fraud cases have paid him handsomely.Shockingly, one that he worked for before he was an MP represented ­terror suspects including Abu Qatada.The leading anti-Brexiteer, who lives in a swanky North London house worth £.million, even earned thousands of pounds as an advisor while Gibraltar tried to nobble Brexit.Sir Kier may be the bookie’s favourite to become the next Labour leader.But down-to-earth voters will never buy his “man of the people” pose.The BBC’s inherent liberal bias is never far from the surface.So it is unsurprising that the Corporation couldn’t resist a swipe at Brexit hours before we left the EU.It’s disgraceful the Beeb sought to mock Britain in a film aimed at kids. Anti-Brexit comedian Nish Kumar hosted the Horrible Histories “special” song on CBBC, branded on Twitter as “British things . . . turns out there’s hardly any”.Its desperately unfunny attempt to present a “woke“ version of history by sending up the Royal Family while highlighting the slave trade was little more than thinly-veiled propaganda.It is grotesque that children should be subjected to such brainwashing.BRITS stranded in snake flu-ridden China have been going through hell.So it’s bizarre that our man in Wuhan had flown back home just as the deadly epidemic swept through the area.Consul Gareth Hoar apparently boarded a plane hours before the city went into lockdown when it should have been blindingly obvious that an emergency was developing.So which bungler thought it was a good idea to let the consul come home before stranded Britons Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit european union mojo back
story: The church bells rang in Norwich and Newcastle and Cardf and Bristol. Brexit parties were held from Cornwall to Cumbria.Parliament Square was awash with Union Jacks as Nigel Farage had a beano that he had been planning for  years, chucking a metaphorical milkshake over everyone who ever dissed him.But this was not VE Day.Where Brexit was celebrated, the mood was one of patriotic pride rather than euphoria unbound.This was a very British departure — respectful, self-effacing and anxious not to cause offence.We refrained from sticking up two fingers. We were scrupulously polite.The UK started le outside the EU with no Big Ben ringing the chimes of freedom, no firework display setting the post-Brexit sky ablaze, no laser show on the white clfs of Dover.The big moment came at pm rather than midnight — the UK, now as always, a little out of step with our continental cousins in Brussels — so it did not even feel like New Year’s Eve.By midnight — already am in sleepy old Brussels — the party was winding down.As we left the EU, Downing Street lit up with red, white and blue lasers and an image of Big Ben, complete with a recording of the bongs.But the door of  Downing Street stayed firmly shut as the Prime Minister hosted a private party for staff.For all the nation knew, Boris could have been having an early night with Carrie and Dilyn the dog.Downing Street was as deserted as the Marie Celeste.Here was the strangest thing about Friday night — the total absence of Boris Johnson.The PM had recorded a speech full of optimistic talk about making Brexit a “storming success” and bringing the nation back together.But the BBC and ITV both refused to broadcast the speech, as Downing Street aides had refused to let them film it.Soyou wanted to see what the British Prime Minister said about this truly momentous moment in British history, you could not have seen it on our state broadcaster’s channels. UNBELIEVABLE.The BBC news studio was bathed in Brussels blue, asin mourning — so censoring Boris felt small-minded, ­churlish and petty beyond belief.I strongly suspect that ­refusing to broadcast Boris’s big Brexit-night speech will turn out to be the beginning of the end for the licence fee.If the BBC cannot look like a state broadcaster on a night of historic national importance, then it never will.But we didn’t need the Beeb to tell us that this was history happening before our eyes.The biggest mandate for anything in British history had FINALLY been honoured. Democracy had triumphed.After more than  years inside the European federalist experiment, the British people were masters of their own destiny once more. And while the national mood on Friday night was respectful for the feelings of the losers, perhaps that was because there is no need for ­triumphalism when you know you have won.The clock struck pm and Leavers and Remainers were all suddenly extinct.All those eye-swivelling nutjobs threatening to shove a Brexit p coin up their pious rectums in protest no longer seemed like a threat to ­democracy.They seemed worthy of pity.But after all the toxic ­isions of the past four years, the wounds will not heal quickly.The most vicious insult thrown at those of us who dared to vote to leave the EU was that we would all soon be dead. And so it is a bitter irony to reflect that Tony Blair, Michael Heseltine, John Major, Lord Adonis, Gina Miller, Anna Soubry and all the rest will never live long enough to drag us back into the European Union.At long last, Brexit’s uncivil war is done.And why Because the roots of British democracy run deep.Once we had voted to leave, it was ultimately unthinkable that we would ever remain — despite the fervent wishes of almost the entire British establishment, from the House of Lords and House of Commons to the civil service, the BBC and big business.Once the people had spoken, in the end they had to be obeyed.No parliamentary paralysis could ever stop Brexit. No clever lawyers could thwart it forever.That historic moment on Friday night felt it had an historic inevitability about it.British democracy could not be denied. How did the arrogant, out-of-touch establishment ever imagine they could overrule the largest vote for anything in our history So au revoir, monsieur, and adios, senor and bye-bye, mein liebe herr. Except — we are not leaving Europe, are we We are only leaving the European Union — that unloved, corrupt, expansionist empire.And the British people have nothing but love in their souls for Europe.Here’s the great Brexit irony. The British are probably the most pro-European nation on the continent. We revere European culture, drink their wine, holiday at their beaches, cities and moun-tains, eat their fruit, vegetables and cheese and buy their cars.But the British have always been a lousy fit in the EU.We do not like having leaders who we cannot kick out.We do not enjoy unelected old geezers in foreign cities telling us who can and can’t come into our country.We — one of the oldest democracies in the world, a country that has not been invaded for , years — truly do not need anyone  to make our laws or to tell us what justice looks like.The EU just lost its second-largest contributor while the largest contributor — Germany — teeters on the edge of recession.We should try to be understandingthey sound bitter.Our stormy relationship with the EU has lasted all my adult le.The first time I ever voted was in the  referendum, when I girded my flared jeans and enthusiastically voted “Yes to Europe”.But like my nation, over the course of the decades I fell out of love with the EU.Like my nation, I began to feel that I had been lied to about what the project really meant.Like my nation — and around .million of my countrymen in  — the thought of “ever greater union” made my skin crawl. For I believed with all my heart and soul that my great nation’s identity is worth preserving.Leo Varadkar, the Irish premier, sneers that the UK must “come to terms with the fact that it is now a small country”.Leo’s line is that the UK is now an isolated little rain-lashed rock, cowering timidly off the coast of the mighty European Union empire.But it doesn’t feel like we are a small nation today.It feels like we are a global nation once again, open for business with the world.It feels like we are the world’s sixth-largest economy, a cultural superpower, a warrior nation with a nuclear deterrent and the best armed forces in the world, the oldest parliamentary democracy on the planet and the longest-reigning monarch in history.All of that, plus the new added ingredient of post-Brexit va-va-voom.And in a Europe blighted by fragile coalitions and leaders with feet of blancmange, the UK boasts a popular Prime Minister presiding over the strongest, most stable government in Europe.British democracy has a far longer history than the European Union.If we were a small nation, then we would never have had the guts to leave the EU.If we were a small nation, then after the EU referendum of , we would have done what all those other EU countries did when they came up with a referendum result that Brussels didn’t like.We would have voted again, until Michel Barnier put down his cane.But the UK was always dferent.Unlike so many of our neighbours, we have not known the terror of fascism and communism, we have never experienced the jackboots of an invading army on our land, we have never seen our country chopped up by cruel foreign conquerors.We are a small nation in size but, through the centuries, we have always proved too big to bully.And what now The extremist voices — on both sides of the Brexit debate — will fade away because extremism is never the British way.Even with a year of transition and haggling about trade ahead, Brexit feels like it is slipping into the history books.The EU referendum in the summer of  seems long ago now.But as I recall, all we ever wanted was for our country to be a self-governing, sovereign nation once more and to restore the freedoms bought with the sacrice of the generations who came before us.Big Ben was silent on Friday night, but did you hear the church bells ring in all the faraway towns That is the sound of a country that just got its mojo back.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: streatham maniac security services miracles
story: We don’t know exactly how many jihadis there are out there waiting to murder us. But experts say it is about ,.Most of them are radicalised in the murky backwaters of the dark web and carry out their attacks alone using everyday items as weapons.All that means keeping us safe has become a near impossible task.Yet when a maniac launched himself at two passers-by in Streatham yesterday, plain-clothed police were on the scene immediately. And within minutes, the assailant had been shot dead.The police and MI don’t always get it right. Which is hardly surprising, given it takes about  people to monitor just one suspect properly.But most of the time — against the odds — they do. And we should thank our lucky stars for that.WE never thought that the EU would play fair throughout the trade negotiations.The waning institution is desperate to stop other countries following where Britain has led, and desperate people lash out. But we didn’t bargain for dirty tactics in week one. We were naive.After promising to consider a Canada-style free trade agreement with the UK as part of the WithdrawalAgreement, EU officials are already shamelessly back-pedalling. To secure a deal, they now say we must follow all the bloc’s regulatory rules.They must have known Boris Johnson would never agree to this bizarre bid. Aligning with Europe on everything would entirely defeat the point of Brexit.But they hoped that by showing some muscle, they could make the PM quake with fear and give them the upper hand.It was a woeful miscalculation.Unlike his predecessor, Mr Johnson believes in the UK whole-heartedly. And he has no qualms about telling bullies where to stick it.Brussels had better up its game: independent Britain is a force to be reckoned with.DOES the BBC have a death wish The latest Horrible Histories “comedy” video kicks sand in the faces of ordinary, patriotic Brits.Its warped version of history misses out Britain winning two world wars, a World Cup, dominating global music charts for decades, and creating many of the greatest TV shows of all time.Why  Because for the ultra-liberal BBC, Britain bashing has become a sport.We’ve always felt a certain affection for our state broadcaster. It’s done some cracking work in its time.Butit carries on trying to alienate our children from their own country, it’s doomed. And we won’t mourn its passing. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: faces of the jihadis freed to roam uk streets after early release
story: The ‘kne-obsessed’ -year-old had been serving a three-year term for terror offences - but was set free on automatic early release after just  months, despite security services considering him to be highly dangerous.Shockingly, he is one of around  convicted terrorists who have been released in the UK in the last decade -  and one of  released on licence under the automatic early release scheme, introduced in .According to the Mirror, MI and the police are monitoring at least  jihadi extremists on a daily basis in a bid to keep our streets safe.Many of these jihadis are back living on the same streets where they were radicalised and more are set to be released within months.Kazi Islam served half of an eight year sentence for grooming a teenager with Asperger’s to kill UK soldiers.Islam was jailed in  for trying to persuade Harry Thomas to buy ingredients for pipe bombs, but he was out in .Kazi Rahman, , is Kazi Islams uncle and neighbour - and a convicted terrorist in his own right.In , he was sentenced to nine years imprisonment when he tried to buy missiles to shoot down airliners.Hed also tried to get his hands on a rocket-propelled grenade launcher and Uzi submachine guns.Shockingly, he was released from prison in .Usman Khan was convicted in  for a string of al-Qaeda-inspired terror offences, including a plot to blow up the London Stock Exchange.He was sentenced to an “indeterminate sentence” with a minimum of eight years, but this was overturned on appeal in , allowing Khan to automatically be released.He was allowed out of Belmarsh Prison on temporary release licence in December . He was considered a success story of a Cambridge University rehab programme, having befriended staff including of Jack Merritt and Saskia Jones, who he later stabbed to death before he was shot dead by police on London Bridge in December.He was arrested in  and given an indeterminate sentence which was changed to a fixed-term -year sentence on appeal in , meaning he was eligible for early release.Bangladeshi-born Shah Rahman, , was part of the terror cell that Khan belonged to which plotted to bomb London’s Stock Exchange.He was sentenced to “at least  years” in .It’s unclear as to when he was released on licence.Ibrahim Abdullah-Hassan was arrested in May  immediately after being interviewed on BBC Newsnight and claiming his pal, Michael Adebolajo , was offered a job by MI.Abdullah-Hassan, who was involved with Anjem Choudary’s hate group al-Muhajiroun, was jailed in  for three years for inciting terrorism.It is unclear when he was released.Rebekah Dawson was sentenced to  months in  for posting clips on YouTube glorying the horric murder of Lee Rigby.Dawson, who hailed from Hackney in east London and was  when she was convicted, also made headlines by refusing to remove her face veil.The religious row broke out during Dawsons trial for a separate offence - witness intimidation.She ultimately pleaded guilty to that charge and was sentenced to six months in prison.Rebekah Dawson’s husband, Royal Barnes, was also convicted for videos mocking Lee Rigby’s death.He was handed five years and four months.In one clip, Dawson filmed Barnes laughing as he drove past floral tributes to Rigby.Rasmus was jailed in November  after being caught hiding in a truck at Dover.He’d stowed himself away in a bid to try to join Islamic State. He moved to the UK from South Africa in  and has four kids with three women.Rasmus converted to Islam in . He was sentenced to four years and three months - but it is unclear when he was released.Ahmed, a taxi driver, was arrested in Cheetham Hill, Manchester in August .He was convicted of directing terrorism on behalf of al-Qaeda in December .Ahmed had diaries with invisible ink writing in them which had the details of top al-Qaeda operatives.He was sentenced to  years, but was living in a bail hostel in Manchester by September , as he had spent five years on remand.Houria accidentally dropped a memory stick containing a “mini-encyclopedia of weapons-making” from beneath her burka at Liverpool John Lennon Airport in October .She pleaded guilty to two terror offences.She was sentenced to two years in November , but she was free to go .Terror expert Dr Paul Stott, of the Henry Jackson Society, tells The Sun: “From  there were a lot of people being released in a very short time but the focus seemed to be on those people ing from Syria and Iraq and how dangerous they would be.“It missed the fact that there was a real challenge in the people who were being released whove already got convictions, who missed out on the opportunity to go to Syria and Iraq to live in their ‘perfect society’. So theyre angry, theyre likely to lash out.“When you look at the detail of these last two attacks, its  not organised. Its about flailing about with anger.”One in seven of the convicted terrorists released since  had their sentences reduced or were freed through the early release system.But Dr Stott says that in some cases, prison is strengthening radical views.“With the networks within prisons like-minded people can associate together and reinforce those views,” he says.“We saw that during the conflict in Northern Ireland and I think were clearly seeing it again, with the jihadi prisoners. They are providing mutual support for one another in prison so theyre not being reformed.”But he says terrorists like Amman are acting alone, with no backing from formal organisations.Its a dferent type of terrorism from what we might have seen in earlier decades where its much more centrally directed. These people are taking inspiration from them and then acting themselves.Cardf Student Iqbal called himself “the father of terrorism” and posted over  links to extremist material online.Birmingham postie Mohammed Benares, one of Choudarys henchmen, was caged for two years in  after downloading an online al-Qaeda magazine glorying terrorism.The -year-old was arrested with  copies of Inspire, which detailed how to make bombs and plan atrocities.Police also found copies of a document called  Ways to Serve and Participate in Jihad and speeches by al-Qaeda founder Osama bin Laden.Benares claimed to be “researching” extremism, but was convicted of possessing terrorist information at London’s Southwark Crown Court.Despite the shocking offence, he was released well before his sentence was up.Another of the cell jailed for the Stock Exchange plot with Usman Khan, Rahman was sentenced to five years, in , after admitting to owning copies of an al-Qaeda magazine for terrorist purposes, which included a recipe for a pipe bomb.Released “six months early” because his lawyer argued he was undertaking “de-radicalisation” in jail, he was jailed again in August  for plotting a “mass casualty attack” targeting police or military with two other men.They were caught when a sting operation found a partially complete pipe bomb and meat cleaver with the Arabic word for “nonbeliever” in the car of one of the co-conspirators, Naweed Ali.He’s currently serving le with a minimum of  years over the  conviction.Lat was also part of the Stock Exchange plot and was sentenced to ten years and four months in , plus five more on extended licence.The Mirror reported that he was freed last year.Hussain was freed on December ,  after just  months of a three-year sentence for disseminating terrorist material and encouraging terrorism. He ran a website showing video rants by hate clerics such as Abu Hamza and Abu Qatada.In , he was convicted of collecting money for terrorists in Iraq and got two years.He was freed early despite encouraging terror attacks abroad and making fundraising pleas during speeches at the Regent’s Park Mosque in London.Simon Keeler is a former member of Al-Muhajiroun and now leader of another Islamist group, Ahlus Sunnah wal Jamaah.He was given  days imprisonment after assaulting a police officer during a protest and he was arrested again after fighting a BNP member.He was convicted of terrorist fundraising and inciting terrorism overseas in  and given three years and six months.He was also caught on a train in Hungary without a passport in November .He was convicted in January  of breaching the Terrorism Act for leaving the UK illegally, and was sentenced to two years.London-born covert Trevor Brooks who took the name Abu Izzadeen was convicted on charges of terrorist fund-raising and inciting terrorism overseas on  April , and sentenced to four and a half years in jail. He was released in May , after serving three and a half years, including time on remand.Along with Keeler, he breached the terms of his licence by trying to travel to Turkey and was jailed again for two years in .Souann, then , was arrested at Heathrow in May  as he attempted to travel to Syria to join ISIS and he said he wanted the black flag of ISIS to fly over Downing street.He was jailed for three and a half years at the Old Bailey, in February , but was released a year later.Former Sainsburys shop assistant Ali, from High Wycombe, was jailed for three and a half years, in January , for sharing Islamic State propaganda on WhatsApp.The teenager, radicalised at , was released last year.Imran Mahmood was jailed for nine years in , for his part in a plot to bomb Wootton Bassett and murder the heads of MI and MI.He is believed to have been released in  after serving two thirds of his sentence.Horner was a member of the “Muslim Patrol” who roamed East London attacking members of the public for ‘unIslamic behaviour’.The -year-old convert, who uses the Islamic name Jamaal Uddin, threatened to stab five men for drinking.On December  he was sentenced to  months and released on despite being jailed for more than four years in May  for posting support for ISIS online.Sundays Streatham attack has shone a light on the UKs automatic early release laws - which have been slammed for leaving our neighbourhoods unsafe and allowing jihadists to ignite terror across the nation.ButPM Boris Johnson gets his way, the waves of convicted terrorists ing to the streets could soon become trickles, or nothing at all.Vowing to crack down on the early release of terrorist prisoners, Mr Johnson said today: I think the question that everybody has about the inidual concerned [in the Streatham attack] is, what was he doing out on automatic early release, and why was there no system of scrutiny, no parole system, to check whether he was really a suitable candidate for automatic early release.And that is a very complex legal question. We do think its time to take action.I hope people understand that the anomaly we need to clear up is the process by which some people are still coming out under automatic early release without any kind of scrutiny or parole system.UNDER British law, criminals serving a determinate – or fixed – sentence of less than four years are automatically released from prison halfway through their term.They then spend the remaining half of their sentence on licence, during which they must adhere to certain conditions like good behaviour and staying in touch with their probation officer.This has been the case since , when the provisions of the  Criminal Justice Act were implemented.Lags serving a determinate sentence of more than four years can also be released at the halfway point, but this doesnt happen automatically - title: universal credit rollout delayed again until 2024
story: The troubled six-in-one benefits system was scheduled to be completed by , but its been hit by repeated setbacks and is now seven years behind schedule.The date that everyone is expected to be switched over will be pushed back by nine months until , the DWP said today.Officials said this was because they expected nearly one million people to move over naturally onto the new system due to a change in their situation - but this hasnt happened.But no one is expected to lose money as a result of the move.It was originally meant to be finished by .Everyone who currently applies for the six benefits has to go onto the new scheme, but anyone on old legacy benefits has yet to be switched over.Minister for Welfare Delivery Will Quince said earlier:  “Universal Credit is the biggest change to the welfare system in a generation, bringing together six overlapping benefits into one monthly payment and offering support to some of the most vulnerable people in society.“It is right that we revisit our forecasts and plan, and re-plan accordingly - ensuring that the process is working well for people on benefits.“Claimants will not lose money due to this forecasting change.”The news was set to be revealed in a BBC documentary airing tomorrow - and the change will cost nearly half a billion pounds.Director of Universal Credit, Neil Couling said: I feel very strongly that in trying to make an assessment here we should put the claimants interests here first.This will be dficult for me with Ministers, this will be dficult for me with a whole host of people outside. In Government we have had some good discussions, but they will not be easy either.He added: The alternative would make me feel very uncomfortable.A pilot is still ongoing in Harrogate which is putting people from the old system to the new one - and ministers are mulling how to roll it out nationwide.One million people are already receiving it and by the time the system is fully rolled out in , nearly  million will be on it.But there are big problems with the flagship new system - it takes  weeks to get the first payment and it could leave some families worse off by thousands of pounds a year.And while working families can claim back up to  per cent of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.It’s time to Make Universal Credit work. We want the government to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Join our Universal Credit Facebook group or email UniversalCredit@the-sun to share your story.  Universal Credit: Inside the Welfare State, will air from Tuesday th February, BBC Two, pm

title: david walliams ntas pants
story: “Still to come . . .“Pop royalty, showbiz royalty, a hedgehog, plus my second joke of the evening. Look out for that.”So I did, but still can’t isolate the exact moment it arrived at last week’s National Television Awards, on ITV, where the industry had assembled for the th time and, quite possibly, the last as well.If it was the NTA’s farewell, then it’d be a mercy ­killing for an event where shock results have come along about as regularly as Hezbollah ­isions have arrived at the Changing of the Guard.Five years ago, you could’ve bet the house Ant and Dec would claim their th presenting title, and This ­Morning’s Phillip and Holly would milk their tenth consecutive Best Magazine Show hangover, to the point their long-suffering audience were probably feeling homicidal.This year’s only vague surprise being, it transpired, Ant and Dec thought the same way as the viewers, with Dec admitting they: “Feel more and more sick every year.”There was a flip side to all these set-in-stone voting patterns, of course.The NTAs remained the one place on ­television earth where Mrs Brown’s Boys could be relied upon to beat the massively overrated Fleabag.Considering how regimented the actual voting is, though, the far more remarkable thing about the NTAs is that it’s nearly always a shambolic production.Categories come, go, mutate and ide into three drama sections .Some are accompanied by clips . Others, like New Drama, aren’t. It also whores itself out commercially and jumps on every available bandwagon.So David Mitchell trudged on randomly, dressed as Shakespeare, to promote a stage show, and the Impact Award was given to Gavin  Stacey, when it had “Caroline Flack’s bedside lamp” written all over it.A lot of this was down to the fact the NTAs still don’t know their own mind.They want to be both popular and highbrow, which meant poor old Michael Palin was left describing it as “a hotbed of talent”, while the camera went looking for Tess Daly.Through it all , Ant, Dec and This Morning have endured, and it’s possible to have a bit of sympathy for the production, with such stubbornly repetitive voting habits.The NTAs and ITV really are the authors of most of their own misfortune here, though.Insecure television networks need a Best Magazine category, TV awards don’t.Nor do they need a Best Judge, which was the section that eventually lumbered them with four-times winner David Walliams, the trouserless host — a man whose world begins and ends with himself and, when required to do something , like pay tribute to Nicholas Parsons, performs it with all the sincerity of a “mind the gap” announcement.As luck would have it, however, two very obvious solutions to the hosting problem presented themselves in the audience, on Tuesday.One was Ricky Gervais, who probably wouldn’t do it.The other, in about row , was Bradley Walsh, who stole the entire show by virtue of winning and saying nothing, but pulling all the right faces.Bradley would be the most obvious fit in the event’s history and I’m sure it would be warmly welcomed by most people,only the National Television Awards were worth saving.THREE and a half meandering years it took us to reach Friday night’s pm Brexit countdown.Yet in all that time I can’t remember one occasion when British TV’s satirical shows actually had something laugh-out-loud funny to say on the subject.That’s almost certainly because Have I Got News For You, The Last Leg, The Mash Report and Frankie Boyle’s New World Order all decided their left-of-centre anti-Brexit opinion was far more important than mere comedy.The wonderful irony is that the collective fury and bile has definitely had an effect.It’s made a minor star out of Geoff Norcott, one of those very rare comedians who’s not just a Conservative Leaver, he’s actually likeable as well.As the token voice of Brexit, Channel  and the BBC, very grudgingly, have had to include Geoff on almost every comedy show, including The Last Leg: Countdown To Brexit, where they’ve been trying and failing to screw a laugh out of Adam Hills’ beard for months now.I gave up on the latest attempt after about half an hour, which meant I was still looking for a show to make sense of Britain’s relationship with Europe and had only two reasonable options available, as the clock ticked down to pm.One was calm, sober analysis from the BBC, the other was ITV+’s screening of Love Island.Obviously, I took the more credible option and discovered men in lederhosen were flinging jugs of beer at scantily clad Frauleins while the commentator explained: “We sent a runner to buy strap-on harnesses and stuff poles on them.“The girls’ job is to toss pretzels at the boys and the couple with the least amount of pretzels on their pole at the end is out.”MAN Like Mobeen Man don’t like Mobeen.THE dressing-up box brigade lulled me into a  sense of security, at Sunday night’s Baftas, on BBC.True, host Graham Norton made sure there was an undercurrent of hostility to “white men” , from the start, and there was all the usual self-aggrandising flannel about “giving a voice to the voiceless”.But Andy “Gollum” Serkis made a two-minute -second speech, accepting his Outstanding Contribution award, that was so beautully judged it seemed to pacy them for nearly an hour and a half.Then Rebel Wilsonjoked that it was only sexism that stopped her joining Martin Scorsese and Sam Mendes in the Best Director category and it was like she’d flipped a switch on the entire room.Suddenly, Joaquin Phoenix was agonising about “systemic racism” and Prince William was lecturing everyone about “ersity” without the entire Royal Albert Hall gasping at his brass neck.Then, just when I thought it couldn’t get worse, up popped Hugh Grant to announce he was so impressed with the Best Film contenders His Lordship had actually condescended to vote for one of them, which I’m assuming lost.For a couple of seconds at least, though, it really was possible to think, “Maybe the National TV Awards weren’t so bad, after all.”WINTERWATCH, prediction of the week, Iolo Williams to Chris Packham: “In ten years’ time, we’ll probably have penduline tits.”Arthritic groins, Spacehopper-sized prostates and chronic flatulence.Further to last week’s allegations, Good Morning Britain weather girl Laura Tobin says: “I do not crave attention. I like to have attention for my work, good climate change stories and Nasa trips.”As I noticed myself, when I saw Laura appear in Tipping Point: Lucky Stars, Drive, with Vernon Kay, Pointless Celebrities and Sharknado : Global Swarming.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eus last words brexit good riddance
story: Croatian ambassador Irena Andrassy made the hilarious mishap while chairing the UK’s final ever meeting of EU envoys as a member.The FT reported she made the gaffe to her UK counterpart Tim Barrow in a room filled with other diplomats.Believing the term to mean “good luck”, Ms Andrassy signed off Britain’s  years of membership by declaring “good riddance”.Despite some fury over Britain walking away from the bloc, those in the room insisted the comment was a mistake and not an insult.The meeting came just two days before Boris Johnson finally delivered Brexit with Britain leaving at pm last Friday.Now the Prime Minister is racing to deliver a bumper trade deal by the end of the year.An agreement must be in place by the end of the  month-long transition period that expires on December  or both sides face punishing trade quotas and tarfs on exports.Laying down the gauntlet yesterday, the PM declared: “We have made our choice we want a comprehensive free trade agreement, similar to Canada’s.“But in the very unlikely event that we do not succeed, then our trade will have to be based on our existing Withdrawal Agreement with the EU.“The question is whether we agree a trading relationship with the EU comparable to Canada’s – or more like Australia’s.”

Still no apology.BBC Parliament finally tweeted an apology this morning.They wrote: We sincerely apologise for this mistake. Sometimes we incorrectly identy MPs at the moment when they stand to speak. This error was immediately corrected on screen.The Beeb has been getting a beating over racial mistakes after it used a picture of LeBron James in its coverage of the death of Kobe Bryant.BBCs News at Ten programme mixed up pictures of James and Bryant just over a week ago in its report on the death of Byrant and his -year-old daughter Gianna in a helicopter crash.Newsreader Reeta Chakrabarti apologised for the error.She said: In our coverage of the death of Kobe Bryant, in one section of the report, we mistakenly showed pictures of another basketball player, LeBron James.We do apologise for the error.Editor of BBC News at Six and Ten Paul Royall backed up the apology.He wrote on twitter: We apologise for the human error which fell below our usual standards on the programme.

title: one eyed dog nicknamed kevin born thailand cyclops
story: The mutant mutt - nicknamed Kevin after the Minions cartoon character - was in a litter of two in Chachoengsao, central Thailand.The abnormal pooch has only one eye in the middle of his head and a unique snout with large lips - more like a monkey than a dog.His mum is an Aspin, a breed indigenous to the Philippines but its not clear what breed Kevins dad is.But two days after his birth on Sunday morning, Kevin is reported to be fit and healthy currently, while being bottle-fed every day.However, unfortunately while most dogs of Kevins breed will live to around -years-old, the little cyclopss le-span could be dramatically reduced by his disabilities.While dogs can easily adapt to le with one eye, its Kevins other deformities - for instance, his unique-shaped snout - that could cause problems down the line.He may have to have surgery to re-align some of his deformities, especiallythey have a major effect on his quality of le.Heartbreakingly, similar cases in the past havent seen the pups live longer than a few weeks.But for now, footage shows the newborn pup enjoying the company of his mother, Khainui, brother Mah, and owners Somjai Phummaman, , and Amphan, , at the their home.In the footage the curious dog can be seen wriggling around with his brother and happily wagging his tail.Owner Somjai, a government worker, said he was getting dressed when he noticed his dog giving birth to Kevin and Mah.Somjai put them in a basket to keep warm then noticed the fascinating mutationSomjai said residents who visited the home pointed out the puppys likeness to the cartoon character Kevin from the popular animated Minions film.He said: We are wishing that the puppy survives, even though it has a deformity. We want to keep him as a pet until he grows up.Everybody has been amazed by him and saying that it is lucky sign.People said that he looks like the yellow cartoon character with one eye, so we can nickname him after that.Somjais daughter, Parn, said all the family were delighted to have a newborn puppy with the physical abnormality.It is still not clearthe dogs single eye willproperly as it typically takes around two months for a dogs sight to develop fully.She said: We have taken good care of the puppy so far.He cannot be breastfed the proper way, so we have to hand feed him with the milk bottle.After the news was spread across the village, other neighbours came to Somjais house to see the lucky puppy, using the day he was born for their lottery numbers.Somjai added there were many friends asking him to give them the pup, but he wants to keep him.He said: The puppy and mother dog Khainui are both healthy so our family will raise them by ourselves.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tui tenerife holiday family undercooked food
story: Nicholas Hewitt, , and his we Natasha Hewitt, , stayed at Landmar Costa Los Gigantes in Tenere with his sister-in-law and her three-year-old daughter over the new year period.Mr Hewitt claims three of them fell sick while staying at the all-inclusive resort - and blame it on food at the hotel they believe was undercooked.He shared photos on social media of eggs he says were still liquid, chicken apparently under-cooked and sausages still bright pink in the middle.Mr Hewitt, from Sheffield, South Yorks, said he started “throwing up” on the third day of their holiday after only eating at the resort.But the hotel said there were over , guests that week and nobody  reported being ill, adding Mr Hewitt did not go to the doctor’s despite advice from the resort and TUI.TUI confirmed they were discussing the complaint further with the family.Mr Hewitt said: One morning we were served what was supposed to be scrambled eggs however it looked more like soup.It looked like they scrambled the eggs by regurgitating them.”He said on the third day he started throwing up and did so for four days, but admits he did not see a doctor.A TUI spokesperson said: Were very sorry to hear of Mr and Mrs Hewitts experience in Tenere and we understand this would have been disappointing.Were contacting the customer directly to discuss this further.Wed like to reassure customers that all of the hotels we feature are regularly audited to ensure they meet hygiene, safety and comfort standards and we take matters like this very seriously.A spokesman for Landmar Costa Los Gigantes said: After checking our internal clients report we could not find any evidence of an official confirmation that the gastroenteritis was produced by food ingestion.As far as we are aware Mr Hewitt never went to the doctors to get tested for food poisoning despite the advice of ourselves and the Travel Operator.

title: what is national minimum wage uk
story: But what is it now and what will it increase to The National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .In April , the National Living Wage was increased by  pence-an-hour to £..And in December , Sajid Javid announced a Living Wage increase of p to £., giving a boost to all those over .But the great news is that there are increases across the board for all age groups and those on apprenticeship schemes.Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced there will be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from £. to £. an hour in April.The .% rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimum’s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra £ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailLabour faces a huge challenge to rebuild its Red Wall – the heartland seats the Tories won at the general election.Candidates to succeed Jeremy Corbyn must make winning them back a priority – and will outline their plans at the Mirror hustings in Dudley on Sunday.With Britain now outside the EU, Deputy Political Editor BEN GLAZE is on a week-long tour of constituencies which ditched Labour in December and switched their votes to the Conservatives.Today, he is in Sedgefield, County Durham. Labouraposs long road back to power after the  election disaster arguably began here in Sedgefield. Margaret Thatcher scooped a -seat majority and Michael Footaposs No dreams were shattered. But in Sedgefield, County Durham, voters elected Tony Blair their MP for the first time. Eleven years later he became Labour leader and in  he marched the party back into government after  years in the wilderness.  After three general election victories and a decade in Downing Street, he quit undefeated as Prime Minister. But  years after he left Parliament, his former stronghold is held by the Conservatives – one of the Red Wall bricks which crumbled on December . His key ally, Phil Wilson, won his friendaposs old seat in  and was MP until last yearaposs general election where Boris Johnson netted an -seat majority. Mr Wilson admitted: “Voters didnapost like Jeremy Corbyn and they felt betrayed by what we had become.” The former union activist was one of the local Labour members who spotted Mr Blairaposs potential in the early s.  He believes Labour has been exiled from office because it failed to keep up with voters. “I have got nothing against the world changing but for the Labour Party to keep up with it itaposs got to change too with the times,” warned Mr Wilson. “Tony Blair knew the Labour Party had to changeit was ever to get elected again. “You donapost have to agree with everything he did, but why have you go to diss his reputation  “I would have thought you would be proud of the fact we were in power for  years and achieved things from the minimum wage to all the investment in the health service, to keeping the Tories out of power for the longest period since the  Century. “But we vily him.” He added: “What is the point of principle without power ” Labouraposs grip on Sedgefield lasted  years from  until December. When Mr Blair became PM in , he won the constituency with a , majority. He welcomed US President George Bush to the town of Sedgefield in November , eight months after the then PM controversially sent British troops into Iraq alongside their American comrades. The pair tucked into fish and chips at the Dun Cow Inn, Mr Blairaposs favourite pub.The dish cost £. in  and is £. today. The former Labour leaderaposs majorities in Sedgefield at six general elections averaged ,. Critics believe his closeness to Bush and the Iraq War alienated his support base, ultimately propelling Mr Corbyn into the top job. But Mr Wilson said: “If it hadnapost have been Iraq, for people like Jeremy Corbyn it would have been something . “Apparently itaposs the whole neo-liberal approach to the economy, whatever that means.” Mr Wilson won an , majority in  and averaged , over three general elections. In  his majority was , but in December Tory Paul Howell won the constituency with a , majority on a .% swing. Mr Wilson was not surprised at losing in , having expected defeat two years earlier. “We were picking up on the doorsteps even before  that it was the state of the Labour Party, the leadership, Jeremy Corbyn and his world view,” he said.  “A lot of us thought we were going to get a real drubbing.” He blamed the leadership rather than Brexit for Labouraposs thumping defeat two years later. “For every one person we got on Brexit, youaposd get four or five people who just didnapost like Jeremy Corbyn,” he said. “It would be that he was too left-wing, a communist, he doesnapost like this country – they saw him as being associated with terrorists. “Then we had the wish list otherwise known as the Labour manesto. “I would get up in the morning, put the radio on and there would be another pledge.  “It got to the point where I just used to laugh, shake my head and turn the radio off because I was thinking, aposThis is just crazy, you canapost go on like thisapos. “We werenapost realistic. “I got the impression with the manesto that somebody was sitting in a room with a pen and paper and there was a queue of interest groups at the door that came in one at a time and they were asked what they wanted and that was just put in the manesto.” Voters were more “economically literate” than the party hierarchy, he claimed. “They knew two and two didnapost make five, but the Labour Party seemed to think it did.” AskedLabour deserved to lose, he replied: “Yes”, adding: “But Boris Johnson didnapost deserve to win.” He went on: “What upsets me the most is that people who are normally our supporters didnapost feel they could vote for us. “People had made their minds up that Labour was not serious about winning anymore.” Voters turned away from the party because they “no longer thought it was for them”. “There was a perception where people thought the party was nasty,” he said. “People always thought the Tory Party was nasty, but now it was us.” Voters did not believe the party was patriotic, he added.  “Thereaposs nothing wrong in being proud of your country,” said Mr Wilson. “But it was asthe leadership didnapost realise the first principle of any government is to defend the country and its people, and people didnapost think we would do that. “People thought we fraternised more with our foes than with our friends.” He identied Ed Milibandaposs  leadership victory as the moment it “all started to go wrong” for Labour – and accused the current hierarchy of failing to understand aspiration. “When I was  my dad said to me, aposYou can do whatever you want, son, but youaposre not going down the pitapos,” he said. “He worked down the pit best part of  years. What he wanted was better for me than he had himself. “The bedrock of Labour politics is aspiration – to improve the lot of working people. “If you donapost keep up with their aspirations you get left behind. “People talk about left behind communities – itaposs not the communities that are left behind, itaposs the Labour Party.” Brexit also fuelled the  result – and Mr Wilson was the architect of a plan to trigger a second referendum. He was behind a bid to push a Withdrawal Agreement through the Commons, as long as there was another EU referendum. The idea was voters would choose between an exit deal or Remain.  Mr Wilson was accused of delaying Brexit, but he told the Mirror: “Everybody knows Iaposm a Remainer, I canapost deny that, why should I  “But we needed to bring it to a resolution and the best way to do that was to involve the British people.” Stressing voters should have been able to compare the Withdrawal Deal with Leave campaignersapos  boasts, he added: “I wanted to get Brexit over.” Labouraposs next leader needs to distance themselves from five years of Corbynism, he believes. He said: “The first question the electorate will ask is, aposIs this Labour Party completely dferent from the one that Jeremy Corbyn led apos “If they still believe it is in anyway connected with Jeremy Corbyn, we will still have a problem at the ballot box.” At the Golden Lion pub in Sedgefield locals were split over Labour at the general election. But regulars celebrated Brexit with a party on Friday night. Barmaid Joanne Coulter, , stuck with Jeremy Corbynaposs party despite Labour wanting another referendum.  She said: “I voted Out but Iaposve always voted Labour. “My family have always voted Labour – working people round here vote Labour.” However, her pal Carrie Mekins, , a mental health nurse, said: “Iaposve always voted Labour since I was  because itaposs a working party for the working people, and thataposs just what you voted.  “But I voted Conservative this time because Boris wanted to Leave. “Labouraposs core values are for the working people, but this time Brexit was more important. “Labour wanted to do it all again with another referendum. “I wouldnapost say I aposlentapos my vote to the Conservatives, but Leave is what I voted for.” Blasting the delay to departing the EU, she added: “When you vote it is a democracy, we shouldnapost have to wait all these years for it to come about.” In Newton Ayclfe town centre today, morning shoppers were ided on Labour. Barbara Haslin, , who worked in a mental health hospital, normally votes Labour but switched to the Tories in December.  She said: “I thought Boris was going to get more done, he made a lot of sense – even though he is a bit of an idiot – and he had to be given a chance. “I just hope he doesnapost forget the North East. “I didnapost like Jeremy Corbyn, I just didnapost – the way he comes across, I just donapost like the man.” Andy Bayne, , an ex-Royal Marine, voted Labour up to and including the  general election under Tony Blair. But he he has not voted since.  The Brexiteer said: “Blair came out with all these promises, he was going to do this and that, but he didnapost care about us, all he cared about was making money – and he has done. “I have no trust in any politician any more. “Jeremy Corbyn was just the same as Blair – a liar. “ButI see some changes I could vote Labour again. I would like to see ex-Forcesapos men get a fair deal.” Julie-Ann Atkinson, , a full-time mum, has always voted Tory and backed Leave in . “My dad was in the Army so he doesnapost vote Labour, none of us do,” she said.  “The Tories are there for the normal people, not just making the rich richer. “Jeremy Corbyn was filling peopleaposs heads full of rubbish, making promises he couldnapost keep. “He wasnapost going with what people voted for over Brexit, he was trying to prolong Brexit.” Harry March, , who worked in a coal mine and power stations, voted Tory in neighbouring Bishop Auckland, helping Conservative Dehenna Davison oust Labouraposs Helen Goodman.

Kate and Gerry McCann are taking legal action against a ruling by the country’s supreme court, reports the Daily Star. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailStuart Lubbock was killed by one or more of the eight people at a party at TV presenter Michael Barrymoreaposs home, police believe. Dad-of-two Mr Lubbock, , was found dead in an outdoor swimming pool at Barrymoreaposs £million mansion in Roydon, Essex, on March , , after being seriously sexually assaulted. Barrymore, now , and two other men - his ex-lover Jonathan Kenney and dustman Justin Merritt - were arrested and later released without charge, and police say the three have not been completely eliminated from inquiries. Five others who were at the party that night - Merritt’s younger sister Kylie, chef James Futers, and locals Simon Shaw, Claire Jones, then , and Kelly Campbell - have also not been eliminated, according to police  Before the screening of a new Channel  documentary on the case, Mr Lubbockaposs father, Terry, , said he believes Barrymore knows more than he has revealed. He has called for the entertainer to clear your name or put your hands up as Essex Police offer a £, reward for information. On Monday, Detective Chief Inspector Stephen Jennings told reporters that it is likely that at least two people were involved, adding: “One or more of the eight people at this party are responsible for Stuart’s death.” He also said: I believe that he [Stuart] was raped and murdered that night. In September , an inquest found that Mr Lubbock had cocaine and ecstasy in his system, and had drunk the equivalent of nine pints of beer the night he died. With plenty of unanswered questions still lingering, here is a look at the five men and three women who were at the party. Michael Barrymore  Barrymore, born Michael Parker, was arrested on suspicion of serious sexual assault and murder in June . He was told in September that year he would not face charges. Then , he and then-lover Kenney had spent the evening at the the Millennium nightclub in Harlow before inviting locals back to the mansion in the early hours of March , . The Strike It Lucky host left the house after Mr Lubbock was found, and he later told a September  inquest that he felt sick and panicked and ran off after seeing the body. Last year, he spoke about Mr Lubbockaposs death, telling Piers Morganaposs ITV show Le Stories that he couldnapost be more sorry for his behaviour that night.  The one-time Royal Variety Performance host insisted he is  per cent innocent. Barrymore, now living in west London, sued Essex Police and claimed it was a wrongful arrest that had cost him about £.million in lost earnings, but Court of Appeal judges concluded in August  he would be entitled to only nominal damages. His career as a TV presenter came to an end after Mr Lubbockaposs death, and he recently withdrew from the current series of Dancing on Ice, with the showaposs bosses saying he suffered a broken wrist. Jonathan Kenney  Kenney, who worked as a drag queen, was Barrymoreaposs boyfriend at the time of the party almost  years ago. He was also arrested along with Barrymore and Justin Merritt in June . Three months later, he was told he would not be charged. Kenney told police that he and Justin Merritt were in the outdoor hot tub together and they last saw Mr Lubbock alive jumping into the pool and in high spirits. He told detectives that the pair left the hot tub at about .am and then were chatting the master bedroom when Mr Lubbockaposs body was found. Justin Merritt  Merritt, from Harlow, was an unemployed dustman when he attended the party at Barrymoreaposs home. In September , he told an inquest that meat factory supervisor Mr Lubbock had joined him and Kenney in the hot tub, and then went into the pool. Merritt told the hearing: He was ducking under the water and ing about, having a good time. He then went into the pool and was e bombing.  He claimed he had been chatting in the bedroom for  minutes when Barrymore came in, adding: He said there was a geezer floating in the pool. Merritt, who had met Barrymore only hours earlier, dialled  at about .am. He was later arrested and released without charge. Kylie Merritt  At the inquest, Kylie Merritt - Justinaposs younger sister - said she didnapost see an assault on Mr Lubbock. She had met Barrymore for the first time at Millennium earlier in the evening. Simon Shaw  Shaw was a friend of Barrymoreaposs and a local resident. He told the inquest that he jumped into the pool to rescue Mr Lubbock. He said: I ed and grabbed hold of the person. He slipped through my hold and I swam back up to take more air and ed again. I grabbed hold of the person and pulled him up and someone grabbed me. He left the home with Futers after Mr Lubbockaposs body was foundbecause they feared media attention, the inquest heard. James Futers  Futers was a local resident and chef. Explaining how he first met Barrymore, he told the inquest: I was his paper boy when I was a nipper and I had seen him around. He had been to the house in the past and was on his way home from Millennium Club with Shaw, his friend, when he decided to drop in, arriving between am and am. Futers told the inquest that he, Barrymore and Shaw went to Barrymore bedroom for a drunken chat before they found his body. He said: We were going to have a dip in the pool. It looked like there was something down there. Simon jumped in when we realised there was someone at the bottom.  By the time an ambulance arrived, he had left the property with Shaw, the inquest heard. Claire Jones Jones was -years-old when she attended the party. She worked locally as a cashier. She had only met Barrymore for the first time that night. Kelly Campbell Like most of the invited guests, Campbell had only met Barrymore for the first time that evening. She was a friend of fellow party guest Claire Jones. Cause of death aposunknownapos The inquest found that Mr Lubbock had suffered severe anal injuries, which a pathologist said were caused by an object being forced into him. A coroner ruled the cause of death as unascertainable and an open verdict was recorded. On Monday, DCI Jennings told reporters that mistakes were made with the initial investigation after items possibly used in the attack - including a pool thermometer and a door handle - vanished from the crime scene.  But he said he is now confident the force will find the killer and finally secure a conviction, hoping the reward and a documentary - Barrymore: The Body In The Pool, which is due be aired on Channel  on Thursday - will generate new leads after  years. He added: We know not everyone at that party was responsible for what happened, but someone was. We also know that not everyone at that party may know what happened, but someone does. We want the people who do have information to come forward and talk to us -  years is a long time, loyalties change and it is never too late to do the right thing. Some people also arrived at the scene in the hours after Stuartaposs death. They may hold the key information and we would like to hear from them.  It is also possible that iniduals at the party may have told other people what happened that night. aposCome cleanapos Mr Lubbockaposs father, Terry, is confident his sonaposs killer will finally be found and thinks Barrymore could be the key. He said: I think itaposs time he comes clean. Itaposs time now Michael. I think you know more about this than you have said and the focus will be on you. Itaposs time now for you to either clear your name or put your hands up to what happened because you must know. Mr Lubbock added: The pennyaposs dropped now, itaposs time for people to come forward whether they are directly involved or indirectly involved. Any bit of information they have got, they must come forward with that.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAfter bruises began inexplicably appearing on her body, -year-old mum Sarah Armstrong went to see her doctor to get some answers. One week later she was dead leaving a two-year-old daughter motherless and devastating her partner and friends. The health care assistant had noted the bruises along with flu-like symptoms, but assumed she had caught something from working at Aintree Hospital. But those around her were crushed when she suffered a stroke and died one week after her shock diagnosis. Childhood friend Danielle Johnson, , told the Liverpool Echo: No one can believe it, everyone is in bits and shocked. Sarah was coming out in all these bruises and she had been telling me she couldnapost explain where they were coming from. I said you need to get an appointment and go to the doctors. She went to the doctor and they said she would need to get a blood test. On the same day they called her to say aposyou need to go to AE, youaposre going to have to go nowapos. Amazing mum-of-one Sarah, from Fazakerley, was given the heartbreaking news she had acute myeloid leukemia.  Danielle said her friend, who was always laughing, did not realise how serious things were. She wanted her story and pictures to be shared to raise awareness in the hope other people will be able to spot the signs sooner - and maybe save their lives. Sarah was diagnosed with a cancer of the myeloid line of blood cells, on January  and immediately started chemotherapy treatment on January . She died on February . Despite receiving the devastating diagnosis, Danielle said Sarah was very positive and strong even though she faced the gruelling treatment.She said: She was just full of le. I just canapost believe it, we were sitting there laughing the night before she died. She did everything for everyone. She was always laughing and she always made everyone laugh. She was an amazing mum, she just always put everyone first. They started the chemotherapy and she was doing amazing. She was always positive. On February , Danielle said she received a message from Sarahaposs partner, Joel, who told her to call him right away.Devastatingly the mum had suffered a stroke and sadly died that evening, just days into her treatment. Acute myeloid leukemiais a cancer of the myeloid line of blood cells, characterized by the rapid growth of abnormal cells that build up in the bone marrow and blood and interfere with normal blood cells.  Symptoms may include feeling tired, shortness of breath, easy bruising and bleeding, and increased risk of infection. Occasionally, spread may occur to the brain, skin, or gums.

But “Ginny” would neverhome from that fateful paper round in August . And her body would never found. Her parents John and Sheila had separated, and Ginny, , lived with her dad John, his partner Violet, and her daughter Tania. On that fateful day, Violet was at work. Tania was going on holiday to Cornwall with her dad, and at .pm, John drove her to Exeter to catch her coach, leaving Ginny at home. At just after pm, she set off on her blue Kalkhoff bike and rode through Aylesebeare, Devon, out of the village and onto the main road. She collected a bundle of papers from outside the White Horse Inn, and began her round. At .pm, Ginny travelled along Withen Lane. At a small bridge she bumped into her friends, Margaret and Tracey. The girls walked back towards Aylesbeare together, Ginny pushing her bike up a small slope. She hopped back on and cycled ahead. Minutes later, the girls found her bike in the road, the papers spilled from the basket. Her dad John remembered: “Genette’s friends came up to say that they couldn’t find her anywhere and they were pushing her bicycle. I went back with them to the lane... After a very short time Violet said, ‘John, I think we better call the police’.” Within hours, officers were combing the area and the RAF search and rescue helicopter was buzzing overhead. But after months of searching, the investigation eventually wound down. In , John Black was convicted of the murder and rape of three young girls, which led to Devon and Cornwall Police questioning him about Ginny. They were convinced they had their man but in , the CPS said there was insufficient evidence.
